statements.name: PROC SGMAP
statements.description: Identifies the data sets needed for map areas, map response values, and overlay plots.

arguments.name: CYCLEATTRS
arguments.description: specifies that plots are drawn with unique attributes in the graph.

arguments.name: DATTRMAP=
arguments.description: specifies the discrete attribute map data set that you want to use with the procedure.

arguments.name: DESCRIPTION=
arguments.description: specifies a description for the output.

arguments.name: MAPCS=
arguments.description: specifies an alternate coordinate space for the MAPDATA input data set

arguments.name: coordinate-system
arguments.description:
A coordinate system is a reference system that is used to represent the locations of geographic features, imagery, and observations within a common geographic framework. It enables you to integrate map data sets. For example, you can overlay data layers from disparate sources and coordinate systems. Specify one of the following string values as the coordinate system:
• A Proj.4 string                                        (as in the following example). The 900913 (Mercator)                                        coordinate system is another that is supported.
• A Well-Known Text                                        (WKT) string. WKT is a text markup language for representing                                        vector geometry objects on a map. This string is typically                                        found packaged with a shape file (.shp). When you download a                                        shape file, the WKT string is included in the file with the                                        .prj extension. These strings are available in different                                        formats, such as ESRI, HTML, or Open Geospatial Consortium                                        (OGC).
• An EPSG or ESRI                                        code, such as "EPSG:4326" or                                        "ESRI:102531".

arguments.name: MAPDATA=
arguments.description: specifies a data set that contains the coordinates for the boundary points of each map area drawn with a CHOROMAP statement.

arguments.name: MAPRESPDATA=
arguments.description: identifies the data set that contains the response values for the polygonal map areas drawn with the CHOROMAP statement.

arguments.name: NOAUTOLEGEND
arguments.description: disables automatic legends from being generated.

arguments.name: OPAQUE
arguments.description: specifies whether the graph background is opaque or transparent.

arguments.name: NOOPAQUE
arguments.description: specifies whether the graph background is opaque or transparent.

arguments.name: NOCYCLEATTRS
arguments.description: specifies that no plots are drawn with unique attributes in the graph.

arguments.name: PLOTCS=
arguments.description: specifies an alternate coordinate space for the PLOTDATA input data set

arguments.name: coordinate-system
arguments.description:
A coordinate system is a reference system that is used to represent the locations of geographic features, imagery, and observations within a common geographic framework. It enables you to integrate map data sets. For example, you can overlay data layers from disparate sources and coordinate systems. Specify one of the following string values as the coordinate system:
• A Proj.4 string                                        (as in the following example). The 900913 (Mercator)                                        coordinate system is another that is supported.
• A Well-Known Text                                        (WKT) string. WKT is a text markup language for representing                                        vector geometry objects on a map. This string is typically                                        found packaged with a shape file (.shp). When you download a                                        shape file, the WKT string is included in the file with the                                        .prj extension. These strings are available in different                                        formats, such as ESRI, HTML, or Open Geospatial Consortium                                        (OGC).
• An EPSG or ESRI                                        code, such as "EPSG:4326" or                                        "ESRI:102531".

arguments.name: PLOTDATA=
arguments.description: specifies a data set that contains data for the plot overlay.

arguments.name: RATTRMAP=
arguments.description: specifies the range attribute map data set that you want to use with the procedure.

statements.name: STYLEATTRS
statements.description: Specifies global style attributes for a graph. The statement enables you to change colors, markers, and so on, within the procedure, without having to change the ODS style template.

arguments.name: BACKCOLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the background color of the graph area.

arguments.name: DATACOLORS=
arguments.description: specifies the fill colors for the graphics elements.

arguments.name: DATACONTRASTCOLORS=
arguments.description: specifies the contrast colors for the graphics elements, such as lines and markers.

arguments.name: DATALINEPATTERNS=
arguments.description: specifies the list of line patterns for the graph data lines.

arguments.name: DATASYMBOLS=
arguments.description: specifies the list of marker symbols for the graph data.

statements.name: BUBBLE
statements.description: Creates a bubble plot in which two variables determine the location of the bubble centers and a third variable controls the size of the bubble.

arguments.name: X=
arguments.description: specifies the variable for the X axis (longitude). The variable can have a character or numeric value.

arguments.name: Y=
arguments.description: specifies the variable for the Y axis (latitude). The variable can have a character or numeric value.

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the variable that controls the size of the bubbles.

arguments.name: ATTRID=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the ID variable in a discrete attribute map data set.

arguments.name: BRADIUSMAX=
arguments.description: specifies the radius of the largest bubble.

arguments.name: BRADIUSMIN=
arguments.description: specifies the radius of the smallest bubble.

arguments.name: COLORMODEL=
arguments.description: specifies a color ramp that is to be used when mapping numeric response values.

arguments.name: style-element
arguments.description: specifies the name of a style element that defines a two-color ramp or a three-color ramp. A style element that defines a color ramp contains these style attributes:

arguments.name: (color-list)
arguments.description:
specifies a space-separated list of colors to use in the color ramp. The list can contain a mix of color names and color codes.
• You can specify colors                                 using a number of different color-naming schemes. 
• You can use two different                                 color names. All bin colors are calculated as a gradient color                                 between the specified colors.

arguments.name: COLORRESPONSE=
arguments.description: specifies the numeric column that is used to map colors to a gradient legend.

arguments.name: DATALABEL=
arguments.description: displays a label for each data point.

arguments.name: DATALABELATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the appearance of the labels in the plot when you use the DATALABEL= option.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the text. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: FAMILY=
arguments.description: specifies the font family for the text. The SAS ODS styles use TrueType system fonts.

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the font size of the text. You can also specify the unit of measurement. The default unit is pixels.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies the font style of the text.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the font weight of the text.

arguments.name: DATALABELPOS=
arguments.description: specifies the location of the data label with respect to the plot.
arguments.help: DATALABELPOS=BOTTOM | BOTTOMLEFT | BOTTOMRIGHT | CENTER | LEFT | RIGHT | TOP | TOPLEFT | TOPRIGHT

arguments.name: FILL
arguments.description: specifies that the plot bubbles are filled.

arguments.name: FILLATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the fill color and transparency.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the fill color. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: TRANSPARENCY=
arguments.description: specifies the degree of the transparency of the filled area.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: specifies a discrete variable that is used to group the data.

arguments.name: LEGENDLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a label that identifies the plot in the legend.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: assigns a name to a plot overlay.

arguments.name: NOFILL
arguments.description: specifies that plot bubbles are not filled.

arguments.name: NOMISSINGGROUP
arguments.description: specifies that missing values of the group variable are not included in the plot.

arguments.name: OUTLINE
arguments.description: specifies whether the outlines of the bubbles are visible.

arguments.name: RATTRID=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the ID variable in a range attribute map data set.

arguments.name: TIP=
arguments.description: specifies the data tip information to be displayed when the cursor is positioned over the graphics element.

arguments.name: (variable-list)
arguments.description: a space-separated list of variables enclosed in parentheses. Data tips are displayed using the data obtained from the specified variables.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the data tips from this plot.

arguments.name: TIPFORMAT=
arguments.description: applies formats to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: TIPLABEL=
arguments.description: applies labels to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: TRANSPARENCY=
arguments.description: specifies the degree of transparency for the plot.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: specifies an HTML page to be displayed when parts of the plot are selected.

arguments.name: character-variable
arguments.description: specifies a variable that contains a valid HTML page reference (HREF) for each plot element that is to have an active link.

statements.name: CHOROMAP
statements.description: Specifies a two-dimensional map of polygonal areas that can be an outline map or a choropleth map.

arguments.name: response-variable
arguments.description: specifies a variable in the map response data set to use to generate a choropleth map.

arguments.name: ATTRID=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the ID variable in a discrete attribute map data set.

arguments.name: COLORMODEL=
arguments.description: specifies a color ramp that is to be used when mapping numeric response values.

arguments.name: style-element
arguments.description: specifies the name of a style element that defines a two-color ramp or a three-color ramp. A style element that defines a color ramp contains these style attributes:

arguments.name: (color-list)
arguments.description:
specifies a space-separated list of colors to use in the color ramp. The list can contain a mix of color names and color codes.
• You can specify colors                                 using a number of different color-naming schemes. 
• You can use two different                                 color names. All bin colors are calculated as a gradient color                                 between the specified colors.
• You can use a number of                                 color names that is equal to greater than the number of requested                                 levels specified in the NUMLEVELS= option.

arguments.name: DENSITY=
arguments.description: for maps that have a DENSITY variable, specifies the density of map observations that are used.

The value that you specify indicates the maximum value that the DENSITY variable can have for the observation to be displayed. For example, if you specify DENSITY=5, then only observations in the map data set whose DENSITY value is less than or equal to 5 are displayed. Specifying DENSITY=6 displays all the observations in the map data set.

arguments.name: LOW
arguments.description: LOW is equivalent to DENSITY= 1.

arguments.name: MEDIUM
arguments.description: MEDIUM is equivalent to DENSITY= 3.

arguments.name: HIGH
arguments.description: HIGH is equivalent to DENSITY= 6.

arguments.name: DISCRETE
arguments.description: generates a separate response level (color and surface pattern) for each different value of the formatted response variable.

arguments.name: ID=
arguments.description: specifies a variable in the MAPRESPDATA= data set that links to the polygons in the map data set.

arguments.name: LEGENDLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a label that identifies the plot in the legend.

arguments.name: LEVELTYPE=
arguments.description: specifies the binning algorithm to use in determining each response variable level.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: maps the numeric values across a continuous color range.

arguments.name: INTERVAL
arguments.description: bins the numeric values into equal intervals.

arguments.name: QUANTILE
arguments.description: specifies a binning of the numeric values into equivalent (or close thereto), collections of the same number of observations per bin.

arguments.name: LINEATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the appearance of the polygon border line attributes.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the polygon border line. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. For more information, see .

arguments.name: PATTERN=
arguments.description: specifies the line pattern for the border line.

arguments.name: THICKNESS=
arguments.description: specifies the thickness of the line. You can also specify the unit of measure.

arguments.name: MAPID=
arguments.description: specifies a variable in the MAPDATA= data set that is used to draw the CHOROMAP polygons.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: assigns a name for the map.

arguments.name: NUMLEVELS=
arguments.description: specifies the number of response levels to be graphed for the response area.

arguments.name: RATTRID=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the ID variable in a range attribute map data set.

arguments.name: TIP=
arguments.description: specifies the data tip information to be displayed when the cursor is positioned over the graphics element.

arguments.name: (variable-list)
arguments.description: a space-separated list of variables enclosed in parentheses. Data tips are displayed using the data obtained from the specified variables.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the data tips from this plot.

arguments.name: TIPFORMAT=
arguments.description: applies formats to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: TIPLABEL=
arguments.description: applies labels to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: TRANSPARENCY=
arguments.description: specifies the degree of transparency for the plot.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: specifies an HTML page to be displayed when parts of the plot are selected.

arguments.name: character-variable
arguments.description: specifies a variable that contains a valid HTML page reference (HREF) for each plot element that is to have an active link.

statements.name: ESRIMAP
statements.description: Creates a map based on Esri maps.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: Specify the Esri base map that you want to use. An example is:

statements.name: GRADLEGEND
statements.description: generates a continuous legend that maps the data range of a numeric response variable to a range of colors. You can use up to four GRADLEGEND statements in a procedure.

arguments.name: "name"
arguments.description: specifies the name of the plot that you want to include in the legend.

arguments.name: BORDER
arguments.description: specifies that a visible border is drawn around the legend.

arguments.name: EXTRACTSCALE
arguments.description: extracts a scale factor from the tick values and uses it to reduce the tick value width.

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: extracts a named scale. A named scale can be millions, billions, or trillions for values of 999 trillion or less, or a multiple of 10 (denoted as 10^n) for values over 999 trillion. For small fractional tick values, the scale factor is set to ensure that the absolute value of the smallest value is greater than 1. The scale can be millionth, billionth, or trillionth for values of 1 trillionth or more, or a multiple of 1/10 (10^–n) for values less than 1 trillionth.

arguments.name: SCIENTIFIC
arguments.description: extracts a scientific-notation scale. A scientific-notation scale is a multiple of 10 expressed as 10^n for values greater than 1, or a multiple of 1/10 expressed as 10^–n for values less than 1.

arguments.name: INTEGER
arguments.description: specifies that integers are used for the gradient legend.

arguments.name: NOBORDER
arguments.description: specifies that no border is visible around the legend.

arguments.name: POSITION=
arguments.description: specifies the position of the legend within the graph.

arguments.name: BOTTOM
arguments.description: places the legend at the bottom of the graph.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: places the legend at the left side of the graph.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: places the legend at the right side of the graph.

arguments.name: TOP
arguments.description: places the legend at the top of the graph.

arguments.name: TITLE=
arguments.description: specifies whether a title overrides the default title for the legend or is removed altogether.

arguments.name: TITLEATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the appearance of the title.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the text. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: FAMILY=
arguments.description: specifies the font family for the text. The SAS ODS styles use TrueType system fonts.

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the font size of the text. You can also specify the unit of measurement. The default unit is pixels.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies the font style of the text.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the font weight of the text.

statements.name: KEYLEGEND
statements.description: Adds a legend to the plot.

arguments.name: "name–1"
arguments.description: specifies the name of the plot that you want to include in the legend.

arguments.name: AUTOITEMSIZE
arguments.description: specifies that all markers in the legend are sized in proportion to the font size used for the legend value labels.

arguments.name: TITLE=
arguments.description: specifies a title to override the default title for the legend.

arguments.name: TITLEATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the appearance of the title.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the text. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: FAMILY=
arguments.description: specifies the font family for the text. The SAS ODS styles use TrueType system fonts.

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the font size of the text. You can also specify the unit of measurement. The default unit is pixels.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies the font style of the text.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the font weight of the text.

arguments.name: VALUEATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the appearance of the legend value labels.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the text. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: FAMILY=
arguments.description: specifies the font family for the text. The SAS ODS styles use TrueType system fonts.

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the font size of the text. You can also specify the unit of measurement. The default unit is pixels.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies the font style of the text.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the font weight of the text.

statements.name: OPENSTREETMAP
statements.description: Creates a map based on OpenStreetMap (OSM).

arguments.name: X=
arguments.description: specifies the variable for the X axis (longitude).

arguments.name: Y=
arguments.description: specifies the variable for the Y axis (latitude).

arguments.name: ATTRID=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the ID variable in a discrete attribute map data set.

arguments.name: COLORMODEL=
arguments.description: specifies a color ramp that is to be used when mapping numeric response values.

arguments.name: style-element
arguments.description: specifies the name of a style element that defines a two-color ramp or a three-color ramp. A style element that defines a color ramp contains these style attributes:

arguments.name: (color-list)
arguments.description:
specifies a space-separated list of colors to use in the color ramp. The list can contain a mix of color names and color codes.
• You can specify colors                                 using a number of different color-naming schemes. 
• You can use two different                                 color names. All bin colors are calculated as a gradient color                                 between the specified colors.

arguments.name: COLORRESPONSE=
arguments.description: specifies the numeric column that is used to map colors to a gradient legend.

arguments.name: CONTRIBUTEOFFSETS=
arguments.description: specifies whether this plot's space requirements contribute to the calculation of the axis offsets.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: the space requirements for this plot are contributed to the axis offset calculations.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: the space requirements for this plot are not contributed to the axis offset calculations.

arguments.name: (axis-offset-list)
arguments.description: a space-delimited list of specific contributions that this plot makes to the axis offset calculations. The list is one or more of the following values enclosed in parentheses:

arguments.name: DATALABEL=
arguments.description: displays a label for each data point.

arguments.name: DATALABELATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the appearance of the labels in the plot when you use the DATALABEL= option.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the text. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: FAMILY=
arguments.description: specifies the font family for the text. The SAS ODS styles use TrueType system fonts.

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the font size of the text. You can also specify the unit of measurement. The default unit is pixels.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies the font style of the text.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the font weight of the text.

arguments.name: DATALABELPOS=
arguments.description: specifies the location of the data label with respect to the plot.
arguments.help: DATALABELPOS=BOTTOM | BOTTOMLEFT | BOTTOMRIGHT | CENTER | LEFT | RIGHT | TOP | TOPLEFT | TOPRIGHT

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: specifies a discrete variable that is used to group the data.

arguments.name: LEGENDLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a label that identifies the markers from the plot in the legend.

arguments.name: MARKERATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the appearance of the markers in the plot.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the markers. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the size of the markers. You can also specify the unit of measurement. The default unit is pixels.

arguments.name: SYMBOL=
arguments.description: specifies the symbol to use for the marker. The following table shows the marker symbols that you can use.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: assigns a name to a plot overlay.

arguments.name: NOMISSINGGROUP
arguments.description: specifies that missing values of the group variable are not included in the plot.

arguments.name: RATTRID=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the ID variable in a range attribute map data set.

arguments.name: TIP=
arguments.description: specifies the data tip information to be displayed when the cursor is positioned over the graphics element.

arguments.name: (variable-list)
arguments.description: a space-separated list of variables enclosed in parentheses. Data tips are displayed using the data obtained from the specified variables.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the data tips from this plot.

arguments.name: TIPFORMAT=
arguments.description: applies formats to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: TIPLABEL=
arguments.description: applies labels to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: TRANSPARENCY=
arguments.description: specifies the degree of transparency for the plot.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: specifies an HTML page to be displayed when parts of the plot are selected.

arguments.name: character-variable
arguments.description: specifies a variable that contains a valid HTML page reference (HREF) for each plot element that is to have an active link.

arguments.name: X=
arguments.description: specifies the variable for the X axis.

arguments.name: Y=
arguments.description: specifies the variable for the Y axis.

arguments.name: ATTRID=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the ID variable in a discrete attribute map data set.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: specifies a discrete variable that is used to group the data.

arguments.name: LEGENDLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a label that identifies the plot in the legend.

arguments.name: LINEATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the appearance of the series line attributes.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the series line.You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: PATTERN=
arguments.description: specifies the line pattern for the line.

arguments.name: THICKNESS=
arguments.description: specifies the thickness of the line. You can also specify the unit of measure.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: assigns a name to a line plot.

arguments.name: NOMISSINGGROUP
arguments.description: specifies that missing values of the group variable are not included in the plot.

arguments.name: SMOOTHCONNECT
arguments.description: specifies that a smoothed line passes through all vertices.

arguments.name: TIP=
arguments.description: specifies the data tip information to be displayed when the cursor is positioned over the graphics element.

arguments.name: (variable-list)
arguments.description: a space-separated list of variables enclosed in parentheses. Data tips are displayed using the data obtained from the specified variables.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the data tips from this plot.

arguments.name: TIPFORMAT=
arguments.description: applies formats to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: TIPLABEL=
arguments.description: applies labels to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: specifies an HTML page to be displayed when parts of the plot are selected.

arguments.name: character-variable
arguments.description: specifies a variable that contains a valid HTML page reference (HREF) for each plot element that is to have an active link.

statements.name: TEXT
statements.description: Displays the associated text values at (X, Y) locations in the graph. The text can be numbers or characters.

arguments.name: X=
arguments.description: specifies the variable for the X axis (longitude).

arguments.name: Y=
arguments.description: specifies the variable for the Y axis (latitude).

arguments.name: TEXT=
arguments.description: specifies the variable for the text values.

arguments.name: ATTRID=
arguments.description: specifies the value of the ID variable in a discrete attribute map data set.

arguments.name: BACKFILL
arguments.description: displays filled bounding boxes around the text.

arguments.name: BACKLIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies that the text should have a back light of a contrasting color.

arguments.name: COLORMODEL=
arguments.description: specifies a color ramp that is to be used when mapping numeric response values.

arguments.name: style-element
arguments.description: specifies the name of a style element that defines a two-color ramp or a three-color ramp. A style element that defines a color ramp contains these style attributes:

arguments.name: (color-list)
arguments.description:
specifies a space-separated list of colors to use in the color ramp. The list can contain a mix of color names and color codes.
• You can specify colors                                 using a number of different color-naming schemes. 
• You can use two different                                 color names. All bin colors are calculated as a gradient color                                 between the specified colors.

arguments.name: COLORRESPONSE=
arguments.description: specifies the numeric column that is used to map colors to a gradient legend.

arguments.name: CONTRIBUTEOFFSETS=
arguments.description: specifies whether this plot's space requirements contribute to the calculation of the axis offsets.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: the space requirements for this plot are contributed to the axis offset calculations.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: the space requirements for this plot are not contributed to the axis offset calculations.

arguments.name: (axis-offset-list)
arguments.description: a space-delimited list of specific contributions that this plot makes to the axis offset calculations. The list is one or more of the following values enclosed in parentheses:

arguments.name: DISCRETEOFFSET=
arguments.description: specifies an amount to offset all markers from discrete X or Y values.

arguments.name: FILLATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the fill color and transparency.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the fill color. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: TRANSPARENCY=
arguments.description: specifies the degree of the transparency of the filled area.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: specifies a discrete variable that is used to group the data.

arguments.name: LEGENDLABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a label that identifies the plot in the legend.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: assigns a name to a plot overlay.

arguments.name: OUTLINE
arguments.description: displays outlined bounding boxes around the text.

arguments.name: OUTLINEATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the outlines around the text boxes.

arguments.name: PAD=
arguments.description: specifies the amount of extra space that is added inside the text-marker border.

arguments.name: dimension
arguments.description: specifies a dimension to use for the extra space at the left, right, top, and bottom of the text-marker border.

arguments.name: (pad-options)
arguments.description: a space-separated list of one or more of the following name-value-pair options enclosed in parentheses:

arguments.name: POSITION=
arguments.description: specifies the position of the text with respect to the location of the data point.
arguments.help: POSITION=BOTTOM | BOTTOMLEFT | BOTTOMRIGHT | CENTER | LEFT | RIGHT | TOP | TOPLEFT | TOPRIGHT

arguments.name: ROTATE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle of rotation in degrees for the text markers.

arguments.name: SIZEMAX=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum font size for the largest text marker when a response variable is used to size the text-marker font.

arguments.name: SIZEMAXRESPONSE=
arguments.description: specifies the response value that corresponds to the maximum font size for text markers.

arguments.name: SIZEMIN=
arguments.description: specifies the minimum font size for text markers when a response variable is used to size the font for text values.

arguments.name: SIZERESPONSE=
arguments.description: specifies a response variable that is used to determine the font size for each data value.

arguments.name: SPLITCHAR=
arguments.description: specifies one or more characters on which the text is always split.

arguments.name: SPLITCHARNODROP
arguments.description: specifies that the split characters are included in the displayed value.

arguments.name: SPLITJUSTIFY=
arguments.description: specifies the horizontal alignment of the value text that is being split.

arguments.name: SPLITPOLICY=
arguments.description: specifies a policy for avoiding collisions among the text markers.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: does not split the text for text markers that collide.

arguments.name: SPLIT
arguments.description: splits the marker text at a split character only if a split is needed at that character in order to make the text fit the available space. No split occurs at split characters that occur where a split is not needed. If the text does not contain any of the specified split characters, then a split does not occur. In that case, if the text does not fit the available space, then it might collide with the adjoining text markers.

arguments.name: SPLITALWAYS
arguments.description: splits the marker text at every occurrence of a split character. If the text does not contain any of the specified split characters, then a split does not occur.

arguments.name: SPLITWIDTH=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum width of each split line, expressed as a character count.

arguments.name: STRIP
arguments.description: specifies that leading and trailing blanks should be stripped from the marker text before it is displayed.

arguments.name: TEXTATTRS=
arguments.description: specifies the color and font properties of the marker text.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the marker text. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. See .

arguments.name: FAMILY=
arguments.description: specifies the font family for the marker text. The SAS ODS styles use TrueType system fonts.

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the font size of the marker text. You can also specify the unit of measurement. The default unit is pixels.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies the font style of the marker text.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the font weight of the marker text.

arguments.name: TIP=
arguments.description: specifies the data tip information to be displayed when the cursor is positioned over the graphics element.

arguments.name: (variable-list)
arguments.description: a space-separated list of variables enclosed in parentheses. Data tips are displayed using the data obtained from the specified variables.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the data tips from this plot.

arguments.name: TIPFORMAT=
arguments.description: applies formats to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: TIPLABEL=
arguments.description: applies labels to the list of data tip variables that you specify in the TIP= option.

arguments.name: TRANSPARENCY=
arguments.description: specifies the degree of transparency for the plot.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: specifies an HTML page to be displayed when parts of the plot are selected.

arguments.name: character-variable
arguments.description: specifies a variable that contains a valid HTML page reference (HREF) for each plot element that is to have an active link.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, label, and length with one or more variables.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether character variables can be transcoded. Use TRANSCODE=NO to suppress transcoding. Variables with TRANSCODE=NO are not returned.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names one or more variables for SAS to associate with a format. You must specify at least one variable.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies the format that is listed for writing the values of the variables.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: specifies a temporary default format for displaying the values of variables that are not listed in the FORMAT statement. These default formats apply only to the current DATA step; they are not permanently associated with variables in the output data set.

statements.name: LABEL
statements.help:
Form 1: Creates a descriptive label for one or more variables.
LABEL  variable-1=’text-string’ < ...variable-n=’text-string>; 
Form 2: Removes the label from one or more variables.
LABEL  variable-1 = ' ' < ...variable-n=’ ‘>; | variable-1 = < ...variable-n= >

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 bytes.
removes a label from a variable. Enclose a single blank space in quotation marks to remove an existing label. You can remove labels from multiple variables in a single LABEL statement:

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the input data set by specifying certain conditions that each observation must meet before it is available for processing.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that generally consists of a sequence of operands and operators. For more information about where processing, see .
